poem:
Route Five wakes in the half-light,  
its engine a gentle murmur beneath the city’s breath.  
We climb aboard, sneakers scuffing vinyl seats,  
and the world tilts into motion.

At the first stop, the bus exhales a low hum,  
vibrating like a lullaby against your ribs.  
Outside, a shuttered storefront blooms with spray-paint petals—  
scarlet ribbons twisting into secret words.  
We pause, windows fogging,  
the smell of fresh paint tangled with damp concrete.

Down the boulevard, neon signs flicker awake,  
their electric glimmer dancing on puddles.  
Route Five hums again, a crooked song  
that wobbles between heartbeat and engine churn.  
A door opens; a new face steps in,  
carries the scent of roasted beans and early dreams.  

Overhead, strings of wires knit the sky—  
an invisible web humming with unseen currents.  
We lurch forward,  
passing alleyways where laughter rattles ancient bricks,  
where a solitary saxophonist bends sound  
into molten gold.

Graffiti walls become waypoints on a treasure map,  
each tag a prayer scrawled in color:  
a turquoise phoenix, a neon crown,  
a crooked smile scrawled in white.  
We linger, breath caught between stops,  
hands pressed against cold glass.

The city pulses:  
a runaway heart drumming on asphalt,  
footsteps echoing like scattered drums.  
Route Five carries us  
through this electric dream—  
a restless lullaby,  
an open invitation to chaos woven with kindness.  

And when we reach the final turn,  
the hum softens to a whisper,  
leaving sparks of color floating in our veins,  
and the promise of another ride.
